p.span:
The SPEAKER ( Hon.
Tony Smith ) took the chair at 10:00, made an acknowledgement of country and read prayers.
COMMITTEES
Petitions Committee
Report
Mr O'DOWD (Flynn—Deputy Nationals Whip) (10:01): I present the 23rd report of the Petitions Committee for the 46th parliament.
PETITIONS
Mr O'DOWD (Flynn—Deputy Nationals Whip) (10:01): I present the following 39 petitions:
National Disability Insurance Scheme
The reason for this petition are as follows

Many Lac's and persons directly from NDIS act as if the funding is coming straight from their own personal pockets, it feels most don't have a background in disability, don't understand what disabled persons need, what works for individual persons rather than lumping a disability in one basket, they are playing games with vulnerable people and their lives.

We therefore ask the House to ensure Participants and their carers/families are listened to, believed, respected, to understand what the participant requires most to enable them to best quality of life and independence without prejudice. That anyone dealing with the participant or family has full training in the disability being discussed, without staffs own opinions being put in, that therapists that work with the participant are acknowledged to quote required access at planning stage.
from 4 citizens (Petition No. EN2268)
Trade with China

In the field of international trade and economics, China continues to frequently adopt economic sanctions and trade measures against countries such as Australia and the United States to combat the economic development of other countries.
We therefore ask the House to China must be countered! Intensify efforts to increase tariffs and continue economic sanctions against China.
from 5 citizens (Petition No. EN2269)
Telecommunications
In the modern age where internet and telecommunications is a necessity, Optus must be held accountable for its blatant disregard for its Australian consumers.
Optus has consistently showcased their disregard of customer service for Australians for multiple years though several factual sources of data and it must be held accountable for its actions.

We therefore ask the House to place an inquiry into the telecommunications sectors ability to service Australians in the next 5 years, seek admission from Optus that's its customer service is unfit for Australians and a clear pathway of improvement that needs to be provided by Optus to the House.
from 2 citizens (Petition No. EN2270)
COVID-19: Vaccination

I would like employees the right to refuse any Covid-19 vaccines on ethical, moral or religious grounds especially those vaccines which have been used in the development, testing or production of aborted fetus cell lines from the 1960's. Employees would have the right to refuse any vaccine and thereby not risking losing their employment if they feel forced or that it goes against their conscience on ethical, moral or religious grounds. Employers would not have the right to enforce or coerce any of their employees to receive any Covid-19 vaccine but would be allowed to suggest and encourage their employees to do so according to their conscience.
We therefore ask the House to mandate the right of refusal of any employee in Australia of any Covid-19 vaccine and not risk losing their job.
from 766 citizens (Petition No. EN2272)
Australian Centre for Disease Control
Can we start a petition to set up an Australian Centre for Disease Control?

Each decade of the 21st century has seen increasing numbers and severity of pandemic and epidemics in the world. The current Coronavirus COVID19 has demonstrated the danger they present to the Australian population.
We therefore ask the House to ensure that the federal government set up a properly constituted centre for disease control to ensure a coordinated national response to disease.
from 3 citizens (Petition No. EN2274)
Health Care

Currently Australian women face challenges in accessing surgery for their own personal reproductive choices. Women deserve the same right and access to choose personal sterilisation as men. These challenges are the requirement for a GP referral and the requirement to convince or prove to a GP a requirement outside of not wanting to have children. Men currently are able to book in for a vasectomy without a referral and therefore avoid the need to convince a GP of their personal bodily autonomy. Women deserve this same reproductive right. This right will allow women to avoid gender inequalities in their own personal reproductive choices that too often leave them unable to access medical procedures freely given to men.
We therefore ask the House to allow women to book surgical sterilisation through the public healthcare system without a referral, just as men are able to.
from 6 citizens (Petition No. EN2276)
COVID-19: Australians Overseas

The Government has introduced caps on the number international arrivals. This measure is unethical and unfair to the citizens who are currently overseas. Furthermore, there is no evidence that it helps preventing COVID-19.

Recently the Government has reduced the caps twice. Now less than 4000 people are allowed to enter Australia each week (which seems to include non-citizens such as Chinese students and tennis players), while about 39000 are seeking to return home. As a result, thousands of families have been unsuccessfully trying to return home for months. People overstays their visas in foreign countries breaking the law. Little kids have no school. Thousands Australians have challenging situations whether financially or otherwise.

We therefore ask the House to accept that the citizens who are unable to return home from overseas are actually THE AUSTRALIAN CITIZENS have the same rights and the Government must support them rather than restrict them.
Furthermore, we ask the House:
1. Completely remove entry caps for citizens and residents. These measurements are unethical and inefficient against COVID-19.
2. Use all available government/military facilities, transport and other services to help with arrivals and quarantine.
3. Make arrangements with aircarriers to initiate enough return-home flights from all around the world. These flights must be subsidised by Government in a way that the airfare is reasonably priced.
4. Cover all quarantine expenses related to arrival the Australians from overseas. The quarantine is a Government initiative and it must be payed by the Commonwealth. That's why we pay taxes, right?
from 41 citizens (Petition No. EN2277)
Superannuation

Compulsory super was created in a different economy. When government owned good public services, houses were not commodified and used as a wealth generator and employment was not part time or contracted. Keating also didn't want the 3% pay rise the unions wanted spent in real economy. So he designed a scheme for the ultra rich. Keating superannuation has not been universal for the last 3 decades. The Keating government and ensuing federal governments did not pay compulsory super to any Australian who paused in paid work. Tax concessions cost the federal budget 3.5 billion in 1992. Tax concessions have now reached nearly 35 billion. Paul Keating also acknowledges that superannuation invests wages offshore.
What has compulsory superannuation and all forms of retirement savings with tax concessions done to cost of living, cost of housing and cost of wage suppression?

Superannuation was designed as an austerity measure on people wasting money in economy at 3%! What is 9.5% compulsory super and other forms of retirement savings doing to the real economy. The Australian economy relies on people spending money each and every day. So it is bizarre that so much wages are legislated to leave the real local economies.
New Zealand took compulsory superannuation to the people of New Zealand and 91.8% of New Zealander votes said no to compulsory super.
We therefore ask the House to take compulsory super to a referendum.
from 4 citizens (Petition No. EN2279)
COVID-19: Travel Restrictions

Since March, Australians have adhered to a ban on outbound international travel. At the time of this decision, it was somewhat acceptable due to the growing number of COVID-19 cases worldwide, without any clear method of containment. However, over the past few months, multiple vaccines have been developed and proven safe and effective worldwide. Now, with a method of containment, Australian citizens deserve to be given back their freedom to come and go as they please, so long as they meet health and safety measures. The desire to travel is one of the most powerful forms of motivation, and drive in life, and the lack of choice that has been enforced this past year stands to impact the mental health of many Australians.

We therefore ask the House to lift the prolonged ban on international travel immediately for those who can provide proof of vaccination and a negative COVID-19 test from 7 days prior to departure. These requirements will ensure Australians who wish to exercise their rights to travel, can do so safely, and without becoming a risk to the health of others. The implementation of these health measures will also help increase the uptake of the COVID-19 vaccine, and end this pandemic sooner rather than later.
from 16 citizens (Petition No. EN2280)
COVID 19: Australians Overseas
Asking the house to act immediately to create a safe travel corridor for Australian citizens, families and partners of Australian Citizens to enter Australia.
We therefore ask the House to increase the caps on flights, build capacity in hotel quarantine to accomodate returning citizens.

Create a commercially viable, safe corridor for those entering Australia to reunite with family and partners. Consider the financial, physical and mental health crisis the state run hotel quarantine system with limited capacity is having on Australian citizens and their partners/families.
Allow options for privately funded travellers to pay to enter through these corridors. Consider university students, business travellers.
Allow Australian Citizens to return, today. Allow their partners entry. Not in 6 months, not in coffins, not alone without family and not homeless with no jobs.
from 149 citizens (Petition No. EN2282)
COVID-19: Australians Overseas

Since March 2020 partners have been separated due to border closures. This has placed an immensely painful strain on many Australians, their relationships and their mental health with no end in sight. The current process lacks humanity and is cruel. You have allowed celebrities to enter with no issue, its time you thought of your own citizens and their loved ones.
We therefore ask the House to remove the current exemption process for partners and the weekly caps for partners, to allow immediate entry to Australia so that we may resume our lives together.
from 1175 citizens (Petition No. EN2283)
Temporary Graduate Visas

Subclass 476 Visa Holders have consumed almost 2 years 6 months till today in wait of their lives to come to Australia and gain relevant skills with respect to their engineering disciplines by working here on this visa and contributing millions of dollars to the Australian community and benefit Australian society in various areas.

However, now we are getting ignored by the Department of Home Affairs. Because they are putting two conditions in front of us, which are not feasible, the first condition of these is that we can come to Australia till our MNAA Date (Most of us have MNAA Date ranging from February to April) if we can't come then our visa will get expired automatically after that date. And second is that we have to get a travel exemption for coming to Australia. But unfortunately, the travel exemption authority is not granting us travel exemptions.

Our human rights of work on an already granted visa are being deprived and lead us and our family to horrible mental illness. We appeal travel exemptions and extending or freezing visa validity until borders are fully opened for Subclass 476 Visa Holders not only for skilled worker's future and human rights but also for the recovery of Australia's economy.

We therefore ask the House to not cease our visas without any reasons because there is not our fault that we were not able to come to Australia in the given timeframe and give us travel exemptions by considering extending/freezing visa validity.
from 311 citizens (Petition No. EN2296)
COVID 19: Australians Overseas

There are tens of thousands of Australians stranded overseas during the global COVID-19 pandemic - many medically, financially or visa vulnerable. Reduction of caps from Jan 15-Feb 15 2021 has further complicated the issue.
We therefore ask the House to 1. Establish income-tested support payments so Stranded Australians can afford basic shelter, food and healthcare whilst they remain unable to return home
2.Implement a quarantine queue system for ALL international arrivals into Australia

a.A quarantine booking shall be made and confirmed before travellers book their passage so they can be assured of a place, and not get bumped from their flight and/or "queue jump" Stranded Australians.
b.The queue system shall prioritize ALL international arrivals in the following order of priority
i.Stranded Australians who are medically or financially vulnerable, or who are classified as illegal aliens due to expired visas
ii.Stranded Australians registered with DFAT, in order of registration date
iii.Stranded Australians remaining
iv.Stranded Australians who departed Australia with exemption
v.Other Australian residents - international students, skilled visa, partners etc.
vi.All other classes of international arrivals including business travel, sports & entertainment, and non-citizens
3. Provide coordinated, long-term repatriation flights on the queue system, allowing time to get affairs in order, travel to departing port and obtain pre-flight tests required.
4. Increase quarantine capacity, including federal quarantine options.
5. Allow Stranded Australians to board planes with proof of recovery from a medical professional regardless of a positive PCR test.
6. Provide a vaccine rollout for Stranded Australians.
from 342 citizens (Petition No. EN2298)
International Development Assistance
Mny Australains are strugling to survive now with the stupidity of many State & Fedral Gov Policies ESPECIALLY CLIMATE CHANGE POLICIES.

Especially many elderly cannot get home care packages, find it dificult to buy food eas cost continually go up yearly (WHY WE DO NOT KNOW) many are homeless & many average Australians lifestyle & once available to Australian workers has been remove or reduces (as unemployment & now age pension age incresed ect) YET OUTRAGEOULSY OUR FEDRAL GOVERNEMENT SHAMFULY HAS PLENTY OF MONEY TO THESE ASIAN FUNDS TO THE TUNE OF $2.5 Billion to the Asian Development Fund & now another $14 million to the Pacific Private Sector Development Incentive? WHY?
We therefore ask the House to STOP ALL FUNDING ASIIA DEVELOPMENT FUND & PACIFIC PRIVATE SECTOR DEVELOPMENT FUND NOW & IN THE FUTURE
from 6 citizens (Petition No. EN2299)
Climate Change
We did not vote for these elites who are making many laws that are destroying Australia & are unfair & unequatable
Give us a referndum now!
The people of Australin within the last few Fedral elections have continually DEMONSTRATED THE DID NOT WANT ANY GREEN ENERGIES OR CLIMATE CHANGE RUBBISH PUSHED ONTO THEM.
But the Fedral Gov DOE NOT LISTEN TO THE PEOPLE DO WE DEMAND NOW A REFERNDUM
We therefore ask the House to GET OUT OF THE PARIS AGREEMENT & UNITED NATIONS
GIVE US A REFERNDUM NOW IF THE FEDERAL GOV. REFUSES
from 24 citizens (Petition No. EN2306)
COVID-19: Travel Restrictions

Due to the Covid-19 related travel ban, the parents of Australian citizens and Permanent residents can not enter Australia, as parents are not considered immediate family. Parents are a key part of an emotional support system for immigrants and their families, and as newer members of Australian society immigrants often have no other support networks. We know this pandemic is going to last long and not able to meet or grief or celebrate events together is causing mental and emotional stress. The separation is now having an impact on people's mental health. Other countries like US, UK, Canada are allowing parents of citizens to join them in the country and spend time together during this pandemic.

We therefore ask the House to include parents of Australian citizens and Permanent residents as "immediate family members", which allows them to enter and stay in Australia as per the visa conditions. The parents should be sponsored and supported and will not be a burden on the government or the community. A mandatory 14-day paid quarantine at designated facilities should be applied so to protect the health of the Australian community, but post this at least the family will be able to spend time together.
from 1930 citizens (Petition No. EN2311)
Immigration
I would like you to allow me and my family for coming back to Australia for many reasons:
- To continue of my PhD study and my family studying. I got difficulties with no internet connection.
My kids got frustrated for missing their school.
- It is very hard for us to stay in our country and study online due to not have and own a house. All our
basic and essential things of life are left there in Australia. We are staying at a motel for two months which cost us much and still have to pay for Australian Storage at Australia.

- Personal reason which impact me for being regret of travailing out Australia. I am overthinking of what could happened if I can't return back since I am got a full scholarship from University of Jazan in KSA. I have received a letter from my supervisor to support my request.

- We have paid our kids school as well. They will be affected in their education because we are in Saudi Arabia in the middle of an education year. It is really hard for them to join the school. They are very happy at Australian school.
- My husband also has to continue his medical procedural for his knees. He has schedule for doing its surgery, but due to COVID-19 he has to delay it.
We therefore ask the House to Grant me and my family an exemption of travel entry to get back to Australia.
from 6 citizens (Petition No. EN2313)
Vaccination

We note that the USA spent approx $4 Billion during the last 12 months on compensation for vaccination side-effects. They are now looking at doubling the allocation in the budget for side-effects in the next 12 months - presumably because of the covid vaccination. We also note that a substantial amount of the compensation was for autism and ASD as a result of vaccination. It is absolutely clear, that vaccinations are NOT safe and side effects are NOT known.

We therefore ask the House to firstly, legislate that no vaccination in Australia can be made compulsory and secondly, that it is illegal to discriminate in any way, against people who chose the healthy option and refuse to vaccinate.
from 545 citizens (Petition No. EN2314)
Cashless Payment Systems

We note that many aged people and people with disability who have difficulty managing money, struggle with the cashless payment systems that are being developed. There is no legitimate reason any business should refuse to accept Australian Legal Tender. This is pure discrimination designed to maximize profits for business at the expense of rights (and convenience) of the individual. We call on the House to legislate that all businesses that operate within Australia must accept all forms of Australian Legal Tender, including cash.
We therefore ask the House to immediately pass legislation that requires all businesses that operate in Australia to accept all forms of Australian Legal Tender including cash.
from 18 citizens (Petition No. EN2315)
COVID-19: Health

Prevention is far greater than any cure. As of today, there have been 28,730 cases of Coronavirus in Australia, 25,931 recovered and 909 deaths. In 2020, the population of Australia was estimated to be 25,499,884. Currently there are 1,890 infected patients in Australia. 1,889 mild conditions and only 1 who is serious or critical. (99.9% mild and 0.1% critical)

Due to restrictions and lockdowns, many Australians have endured financial hardship, lost their jobs, homes, businesses and in some cases their lives due to suicide. The economy has been destroyed. People have gone without seeing their families and friends, missed out on important life events such as weddings, funerals and births. Our most vulnerable have died alone in nursing homes.

In one study, more than 99% of Covid deaths in Italy had underlining health issues, type 2 diabetes, obesity and heart disease. Healthy diet and exercise are vital in preventing those health conditions and therefore also preventing death and lessening the severity of Covid.

We therefore ask the House to take strong measures in banning all processed foods, drinks, alcohol and cigarettes and mandating healthy eating and exercise. This will also benefit our planet by removing packaged foods and drinks, slowing down global warming and preventing future health pandemics.
from 32 citizens (Petition No. EN2316)
JobKeeper Payment: Tourism Industry

Currently, JobKeeper payments are due to end on 28 March 2021. However, given the recent resurgence of COVID-19 cases in NSW and border closures across Australia (and internationally), the travel and tourism industry continues to be heavily impacted and will continue to suffer the effects of the pandemic at least until the end of 2021.

Unlike other industries such as retail, fitness and certain sectors of hospitality which have seen a rebound in business to sustainable and almost normal operations for a number of months now, travel agencies have not been as fortunate due to sustained domestic and international border restrictions. We have and will continue to experience little to no business or achieve profitability in the foreseeable future.

Travel and tourism is a key contributor to the Australian economy. In order to support and preserve this multi-billion-dollar industry, it is crucial that we receive the government's continual support without which thousands of Australian jobs will be lost.
We therefore ask the House to extend the current JobKeeper payments for travel and tourism agencies beyond its current deadline of 28 March 2021.
from 4 citizens (Petition No. EN2320)
Skilled Visas
Department of Home Affairs has reduced the processing speed of 887 visa by assigning fewer case officers than before, with the most recent available data of only 1 case officer per day.
The Department should reduce the processing timeframe to 6-8 months or fewer because:
1. Speeding up the grant of permanent residency to 887 applicants can boost or help in recovery of Australia economy by encouraging large spending, especially in real estate markets.

2. Most of the 887 applicants will remain in regional Australia even after the grant of 887 visa as we already have established social networks and career in regional Australia, and are unlikely to move to the already overcrowded metropolitan cities.

3. It is unethical for us to wait another 20-26 months for a permanent residency, after fulfilling the obligations of living and working for at least 2 years in regional Australia, while paying taxes and assisted in boosting the regional economy.
4. It is very difficult for us to make big life decisions, such as starting a family or buying the first home, which can be a breach of basic human rights.
5. The processing should be very much straightforward as many of our particulars have been verified through the grant of 489 visa.

We therefore ask the House to request the Department of Home Affairs to speed up the processing of 887 visa application by assigning more case officers to reduce the processing timeframe from 20-26 months to 6-8 months or fewer.
from 2081 citizens (Petition No. EN2321)
COVID-19: Australians Overseas

The Covid-19 pandemic has been the most serious pandemic to face Australia since the Spanish Flu. Over 40,000 Australians are in desperate need to get home: many of whom have been stranded overseas for almost one year, with no income and no accommodation. The Federal-Government's response to the pandemic has been to leave the decision making to the States, leaving Australians overseas with no support. The crisis has turned into a bureaucratic, diplomatic, and business quagmire, particularly when it comes to the cross-border movements of people and goods, and so expecting Australians overseas to be able to navigate such a quagmire by themselves, using commercially available airline routes, is not realistic. It is the Federal-Governments duty and responsibility to support ALL Australians, including those abandoned overseas for almost a year.

We therefore ask the House to create a Federal Flight and Quarantine Program, controlled solely by the Federal-Government. This program will use chartered and military aircraft, and military bases and other facilities (such as stadiums) to quarantine large numbers of Australians coming home. It is time to utilise the vast open land within our country for the good of our citizens. Creating a framework for the government to utilise planes laying dormant on tarmacs across Australia, whilst employing Australian pilots and ground staff put out of work, and developing stronger bilateral ties with countries which we will use as fuel stops along the way home, could be one of the "best things" to come out of this crisis.
from 21 citizens (Petition No. EN2323)
COVID 19: Australians Overseas

The federal government implemented flight arrival caps in July 2020. As of January 2021, almost 40000 Australians are still stranded abroad due to these unnecessary measures. New Zealand has shown that arrival caps are not necessary, and many other countries have successfully repatriated their citizenry without placing them in the many difficult situations we are all experiencing. We understand that COVID-19 poses a risk to all our fellow citizens, regardless of where they are, and we are willing to conform to whatever quarantine measures are put in place, but it is clear the current system is not working for us. While the sentiment of the government and of Australians already on their home soil may be to leave us to our own fate, this fundamentally contradicts what Australia stands for, its values of freedom and prosperity, and the notion that we all deserve a fair go. Most, if not all, are experiencing financial hardships with little help actually getting to us. Separation from family, friends, and our livelihoods is also is taking its toll on our mental and emotional health, the effects of which we will no doubt feel for the rest of our lives. We want to come home. Help us come home.

We therefore ask the House to remove arrival caps for returning Australians, and to ensure safe and equitable quarantine experiences for all returning Australians, regardless of vocation or socioeconomic status.
from 13 citizens (Petition No. EN2324)
National Broadband Network

We are one of few forces to use the limited telstra velocity network that has recently been sold to uniti wireless and can take atleast 2 years to see any improvement (according to uniti wireless via Facebook) the first half of the estate is stuck using this monopolised service over the Christmas period we had no internet for 2 weeks with no fix in sight as telstra had no intention of fixing fast, the estate constantly has internet issues.

Switching to NBN like the new part of the estate would seriously fix this issue and put more money into the community as we will have the option to choose from MULTIPLE service providers with MULTIPLE price ranges instead of $90 for 30mb download and 3mb upload or $110 for 90mb and 5mb CAPPED upload, when with NBN we could spend less for the same download spead and 100%more upload speed. Upload speed is just as important as download and covid 19 has done nothing but prove that I have talked to NBN co and what is stopping them from providing a far better internet service is the government itself.

We therefore ask the House to allow nbnco to rollout in the pre established estate as well as the upcoming extension, the estate could use a reliable internet source and the option to choose their provider most importantly support an australian community by putting more money into it via lower cost internet and higher speed to work from home.
from 56 citizens (Petition No. EN2325)
Small Business: Insurance

The Barra Fun Park is a local family business that has been operating in the outdoor attractions industry for 20 years. We have recently been forced to close due to refusal to renew our public liability insurance. We have been refused by agencies in Australia and accross the world due to our inflatable waterpark. This is not an isolated issue and is affecting places like ours and caravan parks nationally. This is not a case of failing to meet insurer requirements, it is a case of insurance companies being allowed the freedom to redefine risk as to exclude people from the market.

We therefore ask the House to liase with the Small Business And Family Enterprise Ombudsman to develop a solution to the insurance crisis and make insurance attainable for all small businesses. We believe that insurance companies should not be given the freedom to exclude business by their definition of "high risk."
from 285 citizens (Petition No. EN2326)
COVID-19: Australians Overseas

There are thousands of people stuck overseas, feeling abandoned, losing hope, and experiencing severe mental health issues as a result of the cap on the number of people allowed to come home. They are spending money they don't have for same day covid vaccines, only to find that their flights have been cancelled yet again. And the cycle continues. It is ruining them and their faith in the Australian Government.
We therefore ask the House to find a way to urgently boost the number of people who can return home.
from 4 citizens (Petition No. EN2328)
COVID 19: Australians Overseas
Currently, a number of our Australian citizens feel unsupported and uneasy in terms of being able to return to their home country from overseas.
Our citizens should be able to come home with support, and certainty that their travel will proceed without costing them a small fortune.
We therefore ask the House to largely increase the cap for returning citizens and visa holders to travel back to Australia from overseas.

We also ask that the house provide a guarantee that citizens and visa holders will be able to board purchased flights without fear of cancellation or being bumped, regardless of the class of their ticket.
from 12 citizens (Petition No. EN2330)
Climate Change
It is just a disaster on many people of Australia now when the economy is hijacked by the worlds elites who want to dictate & stop the rich investors lying & stop taking money form tax payers.

All tier of Australian Governments need to stop subsidizing these forced, unfair so called Green energies which majority of Australian people continually rejected at many latest elections (we do not want any carbon taxes or subsidized green energies BUT A FAIR ENERGY MARKET including LOW EMISSIONS COAL WHICH IS DIMONIZED) TELL THE FACT OF CLIMATE CHANGE & NOT BRAIN WASHING YOUNG IN OUR EDUCATIONAL SYSTEM & BUSINESSES ALSO FORCING EVERYONE TO TOE THE GREEN CLIMATE CHANGE ) WHY DID OUR FEDRAL GOV. SIGN US ONTO PARIS AGREEMENT WITHOUT PRIOR APPROVAL BY THE PEOPLE OF AUSTRALIA? RERFENDUM NOW IF GOVERNEMTNS KEEP LYING TO US & DO NOT GIVE US A FAIR ENERGY MARKET TO INCLUED COAL. ENERGY PRICES HAVE SKY ROCKETED IN STATES WHERE LEFT LEANING , CLIMATE CHANGE LOVERS HAVE DESTROYED A CHOICE OF CHEAP ENERGY PRODUCED BY COAL ESPECIALLY THE ELDERLY & LOW INCOME PEOPLE. SO HOW IS THIS EQUATABLE IN AUSTRALIA. WHERE IS THE FREEDOM OF CHOICE?
We therefore ask the House to STOP ALL DISINFORMATION ON CLIMATE CHANGE, & ALLOW A FAIR ENERGY MARKET TO INCLUDE LOW EMISSIONS COAL POWER AS IN JAPAN OR OTHER COUNTRIES.
THIS DISINFORMATION NEEDS TO BE INTRODUCE IN OUR EDUCATIONAL SYSTEM, ALL TIER GOVERNEMTNS, MEDIA & ESPECIALLY NOW MANY BUSINESSES.
from 54 citizens (Petition No. EN2331)
Superannuation
IS IS OUTRAGEOUS THAT SUPERNUATION FUNDS IGNOR MEMBERS CHOICE OF THEIR INVESTMENTS.
IF I REFUSE MY INVESTMENTS TO GREEN ENERGIES/PROGRAMS IT SHOULD BE MY CHOICE & RIGHT BUT IWAS REFUSED A CHOICE OF ONLY INVESTING LOW EMISSIONS COAL ONLY TO BE INVESTED IN GREEN ENERGIES/PROGRAMS
EVEN CONTACTING THE FEDERAL MINISTERS TO MY COMPLAINT, THEY REFUSED OR IGNORED MY COMPLAINT & VERTUALLY SID "BAD LUCK"
We therefore ask the House to FREEDOM OF CHOICE OF SUPERNUATION FUND INVESTMENTS FOR THEIR MEMBERS, SUPER FUNDS SHOULD NOT FORCE YOU INTO ONLY SUSTAINABILITY/GREEN ENERGIES OR PROGRAMS.
from 4 citizens (Petition No. EN2332)
Rural and Regional Services: Health

This petition draws to the attention of the House that the residents of Morayfield/Caboolture area are suffering unnecessarily due to growing general practice and urgent care doctor shortages. We believe that designating Morayfield as a Distribution Priority Area, in addition to the suspension of the Health Workforce Certificate requirement for internationally trained doctors, would help increase doctor availability. Our region, Moreton Bay North, is ranked in the lowest socio-economic quintile in Australia, with high rates of smoking, obesity and chronic disease. This includes high proportions of vulnerable age groups, including those aged over 65 and under 14 years. It is expected that the demand for health services will continue to grow exponentially. If there is not adequate provisioning of health services, it will leave few options for vulnerable groups. Difficulties in hiring qualified doctors results in longer wait times and delays in treatment. The continuity of patient care is negatively impacted when chronically ill patients are not able to see a regular family doctor. The introduction of Health Workforce Certificates and identification of Distribution Priority Areas are not reflective of patient needs and are contributing to doctor service shortages in Morayfield/Caboolture.

We therefore ask the House to consider our demographic challenges, our difficulty in securing doctors and the future negative impact on patient care. We humbly ask the House to act and include Morayfield/Caboolture in the Distribution Priority Area and suspend the Health Workforce Certificate requirement to help address current and future doctor shortages in our region.
from 270 citizens (Petition No. EN2333)
Health Care

Dental care, especially primary or essential dental care, is health care. The Australian public deserves a system that does not force them to choose between the ability to live without pain and complications associated with poor dental health, and paying for day-to-day living expenses. An effective public system would pay dividends, allowing more people to participate in the economy and not be financially devastated by an unexpected dental bill; often in the thousands of dollars for simple-but-essential services. In a system where people access Mental Health care and other care such as podiatry through their General Practitioner, it is difficult to understand why Dental Care is not covered in an effective manner. It is common to hear stories of dentists discounting their prices for "non-insured" people by hundreds of dollars, indicating that private health insurance only leads to price gouging.

To quote the Australian Bureau of Statistics (ABS): "People were more likely to delay seeing a dental professional in the last 12 months due to cost than any other health professional. Nearly one in five people (18%), who needed to see a dental professional, delayed seeing or did not see one due to cost compared with one in twenty-five (4%) who delayed seeing or did not see a GP and one in thirteen (8%) who delayed seeing or did not see a medical specialist."
We therefore ask the House to pass measures for Medicare (or another public system) to cover costs of essential or primary dental care for all Australians
from 9300 citizens (Petition No. EN2334)
Australia Day
Change the date of "Australia" Day. I double dare you. Just Imagine...
We therefore ask the House to
Imagine... being told the house of reps can bring change, real change.
Said no one, But Imagine...

The Date. I've heard the date of Australia Day is a reminder for our people of years of repression, fear, murder and massacre. I've also heard the argument, "but cook didn't even arrive in Australia on this date." A white argument for a petty justification.
A date celebrating Years of death when a BRITISH flag was shoved in our people's land. And you claim it's "Australia Day."
Here's my simple solution,
We have a day where we celebrate this country.
We, in this case, would mean all of us.
Imagine...
So let's make the date a time when we can celebrate our country and show a little patriotism together. "Together" being key.

Make the date the first Monday in feb each year. "But Australia day has always been in January" you say as you seem to forget history and forget your privilege. Let's evade the month of massacre and opt for a day, not a date. A time, not a historical stamp and a tradition, not a cover.
The first Monday in February each year. Easy to remember and the date changes each year, as we do.
Every person would get a long weekend to celebrate, or not, in their own way.
Change the date! To no Date!
from 5 citizens (Petition No. EN2336)
Superannuation
With many returning back to New Zealand from Australia, I see the need for these funds to be available to first home buyers to purchase or build a home in New Zealand.

We therefore ask the House to urge the Government to consider making Australian super funds available to first home buyers in New Zealand by amending the rules about the transfer of Australian super funds into KiwiSaver schemes.
from 14 citizens (Petition No. EN2337)
Overseas Students

Singaporean international students are appealing for entry into Australia to resume on-campus learning from Semester 1 2021. Singapore has maintained a low number of COVID-19 cases, but our education remains hindered and compromised by harsh border restrictions. We are frustrated by the lack of support toward our concerns, and hope our return can be facilitated given low COVID-19 transmission risk when travelling between these two countries. Many final-year students have not been on campus, and it is disappointing how we have no assurance about what to expect. There is no concrete plan regarding our education and future, and we have waited with uncertainty and anxiousness. Despite our higher tuition fees, we are expected to continue with virtual classes when universities have opened for physical lessons. Online learning does not offer the same quality and experience as in-person classes, and we may be denied in-person internships while being allocated into classes at unreasonable hours. We should receive equal resources and opportunities, rather than endure largely futile attempts at seeking help -- especially regarding visa extension or course deferment. Stress upon border restrictions has prompted deteriorating mental health. Many of us are also forced to continue paying rent, yet it is difficult to communicate with landlords when out of the country. Singaporean students will willingly fund our quarantine expenses, fully comply with regulations, take COVID-19 tests before and after flight, if approved.
We therefore ask the House to permit Singaporean students' entry into Australia on a voluntary basis to resume on-campus learning.
from 1090 citizens (Petition No. EN2338)
Australian Constitution

This petition from Dying with Dignity ACT Inc. draws to the attention of the House that Section 122 of the Constitution gives unreasonable, enduring power to the Federal Parliament over Australians who live in the territories. It states 'Parliament may make laws for the government of any territory …. and may allow representation of such territory to the extent and on the terms which it thinks fit. '

Since this unreasonable, enduring power unfairly limits the legal rights and rights to representation of any Australian who may live in, or may move to a territory, for whatever reason, it affects all Australians and therefore, we believe that its power should be circumscribed.

The Euthanasia Laws Act passed by the Federal Parliament in 1997, that prevents territories from legislating on euthanasia is a notable example of the misuse of this constitutional power (as underlined above).

We therefore ask the House to prepare a referendum to be put to the Australian electorate at the earliest forthcoming Federal election to change the wording of Section 122 of the Constitution to read as follows.

After any territory placed by the Queen under the authority of and accepted by the Commonwealth or otherwise acquired by the Commonwealth, has governed itself for twenty years the Parliament will make no further laws for it and it will be represented in the Parliament on the same basis as the States.
from 77 citizens (Petition No. EN2341)
Australia Day

January 26th is not Australia Day. Every other day of the year is more Australian as every other day we do not celebrate the genocide, dispossession and violence inflicted on our First Nations people. This day should not divide a national by commemorating the unspeakable things that happened that day in 1788. The 26th of January should be a day to remember and reflect not to celebrate. What monsters celebrate something like that?

Australia Day should bring people together to celebrate the great place that is now our home. The date will change and has changed already in the minds of many Australians. The current date retains support from the nation's biggest political parties. Why? They have no attachment to the day yet are too backwards to change it. Australia is a country for the people not the parties. There is no need to wait another year to have this debate, now is the time to make a difference, now is the time to change the date.
We therefore ask the House to change the date of Australia Day to stop celebrating the murder of the traditional owners of this land.
from 112 citizens (Petition No. EN2342)
Immigration Detention

This petition of certain citizens of Australia draws to the attention of the House that: 1. Refugees/asylum seekers detained in Nauru, transferred from Manus Island to Port Moresby, or transferred to Australia under revoked Medevac laws are subjected to an unfair and different settlement assessment process to the much larger number arriving in Australia by air and applying for asylum; and 2. Refugees that have arrived by boat have been detained in a legal limbo, many for 7 years or more, when they have committed no offence and only sought asylum in accordance with the UN Refugee Convention, a treaty that Australia signed in 1954. 3. The ongoing detention and persecution of refugees/asylum seekers who arrived by boat, with deaths in detention due to lack of adequate care by the Australian government and its agents, is not only excessively expensive but also a stain on Australia's reputation as a good global citizen when we have the capacity to care for many more of the 70 million displaced people on the planet.

We therefore ask the House to: 1. Relocate to Australia all refugees/asylum seekers currently detained offshore by Australia or its agents and release them into the community along with those currently detained in Australia after transfer under revoked Medevac laws. 2. Provide all refugees currently awaiting assessment, or a decision after assessment, with adequate means of support for their health and wellbeing and to facilitate their integration into the Australian community should they be granted residence.
from 115 citizens (Petition No. PN0500)
Falun Gong

This petition of certain citizens of Australia draws to the attention of the House that Falun Gong is a peaceful meditation practice based on the principles of Truthfulness, Compassion and Forbearance. Millions of Falun Gong practitioners in China have been fired, jailed, tortured or killed by the Chinese Communist regime since July 1999. There have been persistent reports of systemic, state-sanctioned organ harvesting from non-consenting prisoners of conscience in China, primarily practitioners of Falun Gong. The Independent China Tribunal, chaired by Sir Geoffrey Nice QC, concluded in its Final Judgement in 2019: "Forced organ harvesting has been committed for years throughout China on a significant scale and that Falun Gong practitioners have been one - and probably the main - source of organ supply" and that crimes against humanity against Falun Gong have been proved "beyond reasonable doubt".

We therefore ask the House to request the Prime Minister, Foreign Minister and Australian government to: 1. Pass a motion or make a statement to openly request an immediate end to the persecution of Falun Gong in China and the immediate release of all Falun Gong practitioners and other prisoners of conscience; 2. Urge China to immediately end the practice of organ harvesting from all prisoners of conscience and conduct a thorough public education campaign to ensure Australians do not unknowingly participate in forced organ harvesting in China; 3. Deny visas and bar entry to Chinese officials and policeman who are involved in the persecution of Falun Gong.
from 2146 citizens (Petition No. PN0501)
Petitions received.
PETITIONS
Responses
Mr O'DOWD (Flynn—Deputy Nationals Whip) (10:01): I present the following 15 ministerial responses to petitions previously presented:
Australia Day
Dear Mr O'Dowd

I am writing in relation to your letter dated 19 October 2020 to the Prime Minister, the Hon Scott Morrison MP, regarding a petition to change the date of Australia Day (EN1670). The Prime Minister asked me to respond on his behalf and I apologise for the delay in replying to your letter.

On occasion the Government has heard some suggestions, such as that of the petition, to change the date of Australia Day. I respectfully disagree with the view that we need to change the date of Australia Day.

Australia Day is a day to reflect on our shared history, its highs and its lows, to respect the stories of others and celebrate our nation, its achievements, but most of all its people. I believe that our story is one of highs and lows, of tragedies and triumphs.
It's a time to reflect on the past 60,000 years of Australian history, our many successes, and our failures, and to be grateful for the free and fair democracy we have created for ourselves today.

On Australia Day we welcome our newest Australians alongside the world's oldest living culture and celebrate our diverse background, and the extraordinary achievements that have made Australia a successful multicultural society.

Of course, 26 January means different things to different people, particularly Indigenous Australians. The fact there is discussion around the date means it is an important date. The reason that 26 January means so much in different ways to different people needs to be harnessed.

We can improve the way we celebrate Australia Day by being more respectful and inclusive. It's important that we reflect on Australia Day on the impact European settlement had on Indigenous Australians and their way of life.
We must and we should include greater recognition of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people's history, traditions and culture. There are important opportunities to tell truth and learn from it.

For example, in Yirrkala in the Northern Territory, Yolngu and Balanda, Aboriginal and non­Aboriginal came together to celebrate Australia Day as one community. Over 500 people, coming together to the Buku Larrnggay Mulka centre in a COVID-safe way, for a Welcome to Country, smoking ceremony and Bungul.
In Sydney, Australia Day started with the WugulOra Morning Ceremony at Barangaroo - WugulOra means 'One Mob' and has been a part of Sydney's Australia Day activities for years.
In Perth, Australia Day afternoon featured the Birak Festival, followed by a light show telling the story of Noongar and Whadjuk people.
We can and we are doing Australia Day better. But there's always more that we can do.

As Ken Wyatt, the Minister for Indigenous Australians, put it: "It is also a journey that for some is difficult, it is raw, and it does hurt in parts - but rather than shy away from this, or dismiss our success, we should come together as one this Australia Day and reach out to better understand the Australian story of others."

And Shadow Minister for Indigenous Australians Linda Burney agrees: "What I'm saying to Australians this Australia Day is, we don't need to change the date, we just need to change the way we observe the day. Take just a moment to learn about our past. Australia is home to the oldest surviving civilisation - more than 60,000 years - on Earth. This is and ought to be a source of pride for all Australians."

I agree with their assessment. It is why we need to focus on honouring our national day more respectfully, more inclusively, so Australia Day can be a day about bringing Australians together as one, not dividing us - because we are all part of the Australian story.

The National Australia Day Council has been asking Australians to do just that- to reflect, respect and celebrate and recognise that we are all part of the Story of Australia. This message was borne out of a desire to make Australia Day more inclusive of the histories, stories and contributions of all Australians, but especially First Nations people.

National Australia Day Council Director and Walbanga and Wadi Wadi woman Alison Page encouraged all Australians to explore their history together on Australia Day in her opinion piece on Australia Day 2021.
The views of the petition have been noted.
Yours sincerely
from the Assistant Minister to the Prime Minister and Cabinet, Mr Morton
Partner Visas
Dear Mr O'Dowd

Thank you for your correspondence of 19 October 2020 enclosing Petition EN1677 concerning the Partner visa program. Your correspondence has been referred to me for response. I apologise for the delay in responding.

It has been the long standing practice of successive governments to manage the orderly delivery of Migration Program outcomes against planning levels, which are set by the Australian Government each year following1 extensive consultation.

The Department of Home Affairs strives to assess visa applications as efficiently and effectively as possible, and in line with the planning levels set by the Government. Factors that impact the processing of applications include the quality and completeness of those applications, applicants' responsiveness to requests for information, and the complexity involved in assessing genuineness, character, health and security requirements.

On 6 October 2020 as part of the 2020-21 Federal Budget, the Government announced a temporary measure to depart from a two-thirds/one-third distribution across the Skill and Family streams of the Migration Program. As a result, the number of places available to Family visa categories in 2020-21 has increased, with 72,300 places allocated to Partner visas. This is an increase of 32,501 places from the 2019-20 planning level of 39,799 places, and is expected to contribute to improving Partner visa processing timeframes.

The increase in planning levels for Partner visas in 2020-21 will support the reunification of Australians with immediate family members during the COVID-19 pandemic, and provide greater certainty for those wanting to settle in Australia with their partners.

The Department continues to process Partner visa applications in line with the requirements set out in the Migration Regulations 1994 during the COVID-19 pandemic. The Department is taking disruptions arising from the pandemic into account when considering visa applications,, and visa applicants are bei1ng given additional time to complete the necessary requirements.

The Government is also aware of the impact of COVID-19-related travel restrictions on visa applicants, including applicants for Partner visas who are currently in Australia. I am pleased to announce that on 30 November 2020, the former Acting Minister for Immigration, Citizenship, Migrant Services and Multicultural Affairs, the Hon Alan Tudge MP, announced that the Government will allow certain Family visa applicants who applied for the visa while they were outside Australia, to be granted while they are in Australia. This temporary concession will be introduced in early 2021 and includes Partner visas.

Detailed information about the measures the Government has taken in response to the COVID-19 pandemic is regularly updated and available on the Department's website at https://covid19.homeaffairs.gov.au. I encourage applicants to visit this website website to stay up to date with the most recent advice.
Thank you for bringing Petition EN1677 to my attention.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Immigration, Citizenship, Migrant Services and Multicultural Affairs, Mr Hawke
Citizenship
Dear Mr O'Dowd

Thank you for your correspondence of 19 October 2020 enclosing Petition EN1697 concerning a request to restart the citizenship tests/interviews or a change in this process. Your correspondence has been referred to me for response.
The Australian Government is committed to maintaining public confidence in the Citizenship Program and ensuring a prosperous, secure and united Australia.
In response to the COVID-19, pandemic, citizenship test appointments were placed on hold as of 23 March 2020, while the Department of Home Affairs developed its COVIDSafe service delivery offerings.
During this time, an online format for citizenship ceremonies was developed.

The introduction of onli.ne ceremonies has been critical in maintaining the Citizenship Program throughout the COVID-19 pandemic. More than 91,800 people acquired Australian citizenship through online ceremonies between 31 March 2020, when online ceremonies commenced, and 31 December 2020.

In total, 163,990 people acquired Australian citizenship at ceremonies from 1 January to 31 December 2020. This includes 21,601 people who acquired at in-person ceremonies since 3 June 2020, when in-person citizenship ceremonies recommenced as COVID-19 restrictions eased in many locations.
Citizenship appointments and tests have recommenced in all of the Department's offices. Appointments have also recommenced in regional sites (managed by Services Australia).

The Department i1s providing additional1 resources and increased opening hours at key locations to ensure that applications can be finalised as quickly as possible, while still' maintaining COVIDSafe arrangements and the integrity of the Citizenship Program. There were 65,481 Australian citizenship tests administered between 1 July and 31 December 2020.

With regard to the alternative suggested as part of Petition EN1697, to waive the citizenship test,. the Australian citizenship test is the vehicle through which an applicant for citizenship by conferral demonstrates they have an understanding of the nature of the application, a basic knowledge of the English language, and an adequate knowledge of Australia, in accordance with paragraphs 21(2)(d) to (f) of the Australian Citizenship Act 2007. The citizenship test includes content on Australian values, and the responsibilities and privileges of Australian citizenship. The citizenship test is an important and necessary step in assessing applications for Australian citizenship by conferral.
Thank you for bringing Petition EN1697 to my attention.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Immigration, Citizenship, Migrant Services and Multicultural Affairs, Mr Hawke
COVID-19: International Travel
Dear Mr O'Dowd

Thank you for your correspondence of 19 October 2020 enclosing Petition EN1698 concerning seeking a review and clarification of Australia's travel restrictions as part of the Australian Government's response to COVID-19.

As you know, to protect Australians from the COVID-19 pandemic, the Government has progressively announced travel restrictions that limit travel to and from Australia. Until further notice, travel restrictions are in place prohibiting travel of au foreign nationals into Australia, and Australian citizens and permanent residents from leaving Australia, unless they fall within certain exempt categories or have been granted an individual exemption by the Commissioner of the Australian Border Force, Mr Michael Outram APM, or authorised decision-makers.

Australia's travel restrictions have been implemented in response to a declared human biosecurity emergency. Declaration of such an emergency empowers the Minister for Health and Aged Care, the Hon Greg Hunt MP, to issue directions and set requirements necessary to prevent or control the entry, emergence, establishment or spread of COVID-19 in Australia. Outgoing travel is being managed by exception during this emergency period.
The travel restrictions have been successful in slowing the spread of COVID-19 in Australia, and were implemented on the advice of the Australian Health Protection Principal Committee.

Travel exemption guidelines and policy settings are reviewed as circumstances in relation to the COVID-19 pandemic evolve. On 17 September 2020, the Commissioner's Guidelines and two Operational Directives were published on the Department of Home Affairs' website to increase transparency about the exemption assessment process and decision-making. These documents are updated regularly as policy evolves, and remain available for members of the public to review.

Whilst I acknowledge the concerns raised through Petition EN1698, the travel restrictions are in place to protect Australians from the potential' health risks posed by international travel. We are looking at how to begin recommencing travel and appreciate the benefits open borders will bring, but it will be a gradual process informed by health advice.
Thank you for bringing Petition EN1698 to my attention. Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Home Affairs, Mr Dutton
COVID-19: International Travel
Dear Mr O'Dowd

Thank you for your correspondence of 19 October 2020 enclosing Petition EN1780 concerning seeking a review of Australia's travel restrictions for immediate family members entering/leaving Australia. Your correspondence has been referred to me as the Minister for Home Affairs as the matter falls within my portfolio responsibilities.

As you know, from 1 February 2020, the Australian Government has progressively announced travel restrictions to curb the introduction and spread of COVID-19 in Australia. From 20 March 2020, travel restrictions have been in place prohibiting travel of all foreign nationals into Australia, unless they fall within certain exempt categories. From 25 March 2020, travel restrictions have been in place prohibiting Australian citizens and permanent residents from leaving Australia, unless they fall within certain exempt categories. The Government recognises the difficulty this presents for individuals and families, who may have been separated due to Australia's and other countries' travel restrictions.
The travel "restrictions have been successful in slowing the spread of COVID-19 in Australia, and were implemented on the advice of the Australian Health Protection Principal Committee.

As you are aware, immediate family members of Australian citizens, Australian permanent residents, and New Zealand citizens usually resident in Australia, are exempt from Australia's travel restrictions. Spouses, de facto partners, dependent children and legal g1uardians are au considered to be immediate family members for the purpose of exemptions to Australia's travel restrictions. Partner (subclasses 100, · 309, 801 and 820) and Child (subclasses 101, 102 and 445) visa holders are able to come to Australia and do not need to request an exemption.

Immediate family members who hold a temporary visa, or do not yet hold a valid visa, must provide documentary evidence of their relationship to the Department of Home Affairs for assessment before seeking to travel to Australia.

Comprehensive information about how to provide documentary evidence of an immediate family relationship can be found on the Department's website at: https://immi.homeaffairs.gov.au/supporting/Pages/evidence-of-relationship.aspx.

Temporary visa holders do not need an exemption to depart Australia. It is open to the temporary visa holder separated from their family to depart Australia to reunite with them. Consideration is given to travel exemption requests from family members of temporary visa holders in Australia who may have a critical skill, and where there is a risk the person will depart if they are unable to reunite with their family.
Consideration is also given to exemption requests from families where a minor is in Australia and was lawfully present in Australia before the restrictions came into effect.

The Australian Border Force Commissioner's Guidelines, the Commissioner's Inwards Decision Making, the Inwards Travel Restrictions Operation Directive and the Outward Travel Restrictions Operation Directive also outlines the circumstances that would generally meet exemption requirements. The guidelines are publicly available on the Department's website at: https://covid19.homeaffairs.gov.au/travel­ restrictions.

Decisions to grant exemptions must be balanced against the Government's intent for imposing the travel restrictions, that is, the potential health risks posed to the Australian community by international travellers.
Further information on travel exemptions is available on the Department's website at: https://covid19.homeaffairs.gov.au. These measures are temporary and are reviewed regularly.
Thank you for bringing Petition EN1780 to my attention.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Home Affairs, Mr Dutton
Regional Sponsored Migration Scheme
Dear Mr O'Dowd

Thank you for your correspondence of 9 November 2020 enclosing, Petition EN1880 concerning the refusal of nomination and visa applications lodged under the Regional Sponsored Migration Scheme (RSMS) (subclass 187) visa program between December 2017 and March 2018. Your correspondence has been referred to me for response.

Petition EN1880 requests that the Department of Home Affairs investigate and provide official reasons for the refusal of RSMS nomination applications between December 2017 and March 2018. 11 can assure the petitioners that decisions on RSMS nomination and visa applications are made only after full and careful consideration, and in accordance with Australia's migration legislation. Under the migration legislation, the decision-maker must refuse an application if they are not satisfied that the applicant meets all prescribed criteria.

The RSMS visa program was introduced in July 2012 to enable employers in regional Australia to nominate skilled overseas workers to fill skills shortages that cannot be addressed by the local labour market. In March 2018, the Australian Government introduced tightened sponsor and visa requirements, including the addition of a requirement that the visa applicant had worked at least three years in the nominated occupation and changing the age requirement from being under 50 to under 45 at the time of application.

Ahead of the changes introduced in March 2018, the Department received an increase in incomplete and poor quality RSMS applications. This led to a slightly higher refusal rate in the months leading to these changes. However, there was no mass rejection of RSMS nomination and visa applications as claimed in Petition EN1880.

Based on departmental records, about 1,374 RSMS nomination applications and 1,681 SMS visa applications were refused during the period December 2017 and March 2018. In general, the RSMS refusal rates increased in recent years, from 11 per cent in 2016-17, to over 35 per cent in 2017-18 and 2018-19. These refusal rates highlight the complexity of the RSMS caseload.

It is important to note that the onus is on the applicant to provide as much information as possible when they lodge their application. The Department is not legally obliged to request further information and can finalise an application based solely on the documentation and information provided with the application.
Each decision record includes details of the reasons for the refusal including the legislative criteria under which the application was refused.
It is also important to note that applicants may seek review of the refusal decision with the Administrative Appeals Tribunal, if they are not satisfied with the Department's decision.

The RSMS visa closed to new applications in the Direct Entry stream on 16 November 2011 9 and was replaced by the Skilled Employer Sponsored Regional (Provisional) (SESR) (subclass 494) visa. The SESR visa is a provisional, visa that assists regional employers to retain their skilled overseas workers and supports regional development.
Further information on the SESR visa is available on the Department's website at:
https://immi.homeaffairs.gov.au/visas/getting-a-vi;sa/visa-li' sting/skilled-employer­ sponsored-regional-494.
Thank you for bringing Petition EN1880 to my attention.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Immigration, Citizenship, Migrant Services and Multicultural Affairs, Mr Hawke
Temporary Graduate Visas
Dear Mr O'Dowd

Thank you for your correspondence of 9 November 2020 enclosing Petition EN1881 concerning Temporary Graduate visa holders and travel exemptions. Your correspondence has been referred to me for response.

The Australian Government understands that travelling to Australia is a critical consideration for students whose studies have been severely disrupted by the COVID-19 pandemic. The Prime Minister's, the Hon Scott Morrison MP, three-step Roadmap to a COVID-safe Australia makes clear that the Government supports the return of international students to Australia. Across government, careful consideration is being given to how and when this can occur in a COVID-safe way.

There is currently no fixed timeline for the return of international students. States and territories will make decisions about how and when to move between steps of the Roadmap based on local conditions and in line with health advice.

Student visa holders outside Australia will not be able to travel to Australia until COVID-19 travel restrictions have been relaxed. The Commissioner of the Australian Border Force, Mr Michael Outram APM, may consider additional exemptions on a case by case basis to enter Aust lia. Applicants can submit a request through the online form available on the Department of Home Affairs' website at: https://covid19.homeaffairs.gov.au/coming-australia#toc-10.

Under Australian Migration legislation, student and temporary graduate visas are unable to be extended. If additional time to complete studies is required, a new visa will need to be lodged with the applicant needing to meet all visa eligibility requirements.

Persons who are residing outside Australia do not need a visa to study with an Australian education provider. The issue of online learning is essentially a matter for the Department of Education, Skills and Employment, and the regulators Tertiary
Education Quality and Standards Agency (TEQSA), and the Australian Skills Quality
Authority (ASQA), rather than a visa issue . ASQA and TEQSA have recently made statements that they will be flexible in order to support students to study online either in Australia or offshore.
Thank you for bringing Petition EN1881 to my attention.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Immigration, Citizenship, Migrant Services and Multicultural Affairs, Mr Hawke
Parliament
Dear Mr O'Dowd

Thank you for your letter dated 9 November 2020, to the Prime Minister, the Hon Scott Morrison MP, regarding a petition to limit tenure for ministers and qualifications for ministers (EN1922). The Prime Minister has asked me to respond on his behalf. I sincerely apologise for the delay in responding to your letter.

The Governor-General appoints Ministers on advice from the Prime Minister. The Australian Constitution sets out a number of requirements for those who can be appointed to the Ministry, including that ministers must be a Member of Parliament. There are no specific requirements for a person to be appointed as the minister for a particular portfolio. Further, the Constitution does not set a time limit for ministers.

A change to the appointment requirements and tenure for ministers would require a change to the Constitution, which can only be amended by referendum. The Australian Government has no plans to commence a referendum process on altering the Constitution for the appointment requirements and tenure of ministers.
from the Assistant Minister to the Prime Minister and Cabinet, Mr Morton
Leaders' Pledge for Nature
Dear Chair

Thank you for your letter of 30 November 2020 to the Minister for Energy and Emissions Reduction, the Hon Angus Taylor MP, concerning petition EN1959 on the Leader's Pledge for Nature. Your correspondence has been referred to me as the Minister for the Environment.

I appreciate the interest of the petitioners on this issue. Biodiversity is everyone's business and all Australians have a role to play in protecting our rich biodiversity into the future. The Australian Government is committed to protecting our unique biodiversity to ensure our important environments and habitats are preserved for future generations of Australians.

We are committed to ambitious global action on biodiversity, including the achievement of the Convention on Biological Diversity 2050 Vision and the successful delivery of an ambitious post-2020 Global Biodiversity Framework. We are also continuing to work domestically to safeguard our unique biodiversity through programs such as the $1 billion Landcare Program and the $149 million National Environmental Science Program. We have committed over $1.9 billion to support the health and resilience of the Great Barrier Reef and $200 million to support the recovery of our wildlife and natural habitats following the 2019-20 bushfires.
Thank you for bringing these concerns to the Government's attention.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for the Environment, Ms Ley
COVID-19: Visitor Visas
Dear Mr O'Dowd

Thank you for your correspondence of 30 November 2020 enclosing Petition EN1978 concerning extending the length of stay for visitors on Visitor (subclass 600) visas until the COVID-19 pandemic ends. Your correspondence has been referred to me for response.
Visitors who are unable to leave Australia before their current visa expires must apply for a new visa and must satisfy the requirements of that visa.

The Department of Home Affairs is aware of the difficulties facing Visitor visa holders and has introduced a number of flexibilities to assist them. Visitor visa applicants are now given additional time to complete required checks and provide documentation in support of their visa applications. If the Department has requested further information and the applicant is unable to provide the information within the timeframe provided, they should contact the Department to provide details via their lmmiAccount. Where necessary, Visitor visas are being granted to allow continuous stay in Australia beyond 12 months in recognition of the current exceptional circumstances.

Visitor visa holders who are unable to return home and require further stay may be eligible for the Temporary Activity (subclass 408) Australian Government Endorsed Event stream (COVID-19 Pandemic event) visa. This visa has been created to assist temporary visa holders in Australia during the COVID-19 pandemic.

Temporary visa holders will need to demonstrate why they cannot meet the requirements for another visa. This could include a statement and evidence that they do not have access to sufficient funds to be able to pay a further visa application charge (VAC). The COVID-119 Pandemic event vi1sa is VAC free.
More information is available on the Department's website at:
https://immi.homeaffairs.gov.au/visas/getting-a-visa/visa-listing/temporary­activity-408/australian-government-endorsed-events-covid-19.

The Department's website contains the latest information on immigration and border arrangements during COVID-19. For more information, I encourage applicants to visit https://covid19.homeaffairs.gov.au.
Thank you for bringing Petition EN1978 to my attention.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Immigration, Citizenship, Migrant Services and Multicultural Affairs, Mr Hawke
Telecommunications
Dear Chair

Thank you for your email of 30 November 2020 to the Minister for Communications, Urban Infrastructure, Cities and the Arts, the Hon Paul Fletcher MP, regarding Petition EN1991. This petition asks the House of Representatives to prioritise Flagstone, Queensland, in the next round of the Government's Mobile Black Spot Program. Your email was referred to me, as this matter falls within my portfolio responsibilities.

Expanding mobile coverage has clear economic, social and public safety benefits for people living, working and travelling in regional and remote areas of Australia. For this reason, the Government has committed $380 million to date to the Mobile Black Spot Program to invest in new mobile base stations that address mobile black spots in regional areas. Round 5A of this program is currently open, with applications from Mobile Network Operators and infrastructure providers closing on 5 March 2021.

Under the first five rounds of the Program, more than 1,200 mobile base stations have been funded across Australia, including two Telstra base stations in the Flagstone area, at New Beith and Undullah. The mobile base station located at New Beith, funded under Round 2 of the Program, commenced operating in August 2019, while the Undullah site, funded under the Priority Locations Round, commenced operating in October 2020.

The coverage provided by these two new base stations is in addition to improved coverage in the 4280 postcode area that is already being provided or is planned by Telstra, Optus and TPG Telecom. This coverage is being generated by base stations at Jimboomba, South MacLean,
North MacLean and two new base stations in the vicinity of the Flagstone Village shopping centre.

Residents in Flagstone should now also have access to high speed broadband services through the roll-out of NBN fixed line and fixed wireless to almost all locations in the area. Residents who are not already connected can check the NBN network availability at their address at: www.nbnco.com.au/connect-home-or-business/check-your-address.

If residents of Flagstone are still experiencing mobile coverage issues despite these recent improvements, I recommend they engage directly with their mobile network operators (MNOs) to make their coverage issues known, and to encourage the MNOs to consider including Flagstone in an application for funding under Round SA of the Mobile Black Spot Program. Past experience has shown that when local communities and councils engage directly with the MNOs, it increases the likelihood that an application for funding for a particular area will be put forward.

The Department of Infrastructure, Transport, Regional Development and Communications also maintains a central register of locations which have been the subject of a complaint concerning poor or non-existent mobile coverage. Following receipt of the petition, Flagstone has been added to the register. This register is made available to all bidders for their consideration when applying for funding under each round of the Program.

Even in areas where there are existing mobile towers, there are a number of factors that can interfere with mobile reception at a particular location. These factors may include the presence of hilly terrain, buildings and other physical obstacles such as trees interrupting the line-of-sight from the nearest base station. Sometimes residents with good outdoor mobile reception can experience reception issues inside their home.

A number of products are available that can improve mobile reception, including an external antenna or an authorised repeater. The most appropriate antenna may depend upon the network and prices can vary. People can obtain advice on the best solution by contacting their service provider or visiting their nearest mobile phone shop or recognised dealer.

Wi-Fi calling is another option that allows customers with a compatible device to call and text over a broadband connection. This can be particularly helpful for those experiencing poor indoor mobile coverage and who have an NBN connection to their home. Customers can obtain further advice about this option by contacting their mobile service provider.
I trust this information is of assistance.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Regional Health, Regional Communications and Local Government, Mr Coulton
Telecommunications
Dear Chair
Thank you for your email of30 November 2020 regarding Petition EN1993, concerning reliable internet and phone reception in the township and district of Woorinen, Victoria.

I note the petitioners' concerns regarding a lack of internet and mobile phone reception disadvantaging residents and businesses in the township and district of Woorinen. The predictive coverage maps published by the mobile network operators (MNOs)- Optus, Telstra and TPG Telecom (formerly Vodafone Hutchinson Australia) indicate that while the Woorinen area receives 3G and 4G handheld mobile coverage, some residents may benefit from the use of an external antenna or authorised repeater to improve their indoor reception.

Even in areas with good coverage, there are a number of factors that can interfere with mobile reception and therefore impact a user's ability to obtain or maintain a mobile signal at any given time or place. These factors include distance from mobile base stations, terrain, buildings (including their internal structure) or other physical obstacles such as trees interrupting the line-of-sight from the nearest mobile base station. Sometimes residents with good outdoor mobile reception can experience reception issues inside their home. I encourage residents to contact their mobile service provider to make their coverage issues known and to identify ways to maximise their reception.

Expanding mobile coverage has clear economic, social and public safety benefits for people living, working and travelling in regional and remote areas of Australia. This is why the Australian Government has committed $380 million to date to the Mobile Black Spot Program (the Program) to invest in telecommunications infrastructure projects which address mobile black spots across Australia. To date, more than 1,200 base stations have been funded under the first five rounds of the Program.

The application process for the next round of the Program, Round 5A, opened on 18 November 2020 with applications from MNOs and infrastructure providers due by 5 March 2021. As part of the Program, $80 million in funding has also been allocated for Round 6, the process for which is expected to commence after the Round 5A competitive assessment process is complete. Further information is available on the Department of Infrastructure, Transport, Regional Development and Communications' website at www.communications.gov.au/mbsp.
